title: George Pérez, DC and Marvel Comic Book Creator, Dies at 67; The acclaimed artist and writer was best known for 'The New Teen Titans,' 'Wonder Woman' and 'Crisis on Infinite Earths'
text:
"To know George was to love him; and he loved back. Fiercely and with his whole heart. The world is a lot less vibrant today without him in it," the family wrote.

Known for his clean and realistic style of penciling, Mr. Pérez began his professional career in 1973 working for Marvel Comics, where he illustrated "The Avengers" and "The Fantastic Four," among others. Mr. Pérez and writer Bill Mantlo co-created the White Tiger, Marvel's first Hispanic superhero.

In 1980, Mr. Pérez moved to DC Comics where he and writer Marv Wolfman launched "The New Teen Titans," a revival of the teen superhero series which became a commercial and critical success.

Messrs. Pérez and Wolfman also collaborated on the seminal crossover event "Crisis on Infinite Earths," which helped reboot and streamline DC's continuity across its comics. He also worked on the sequels "Infinite Crisis" in 2005-06 and "Final Crisis" in 2008-09.

Mr. Pérez went on to relaunch "Wonder Woman" in 1987 and helped to bring the character closer to her Greek mythology roots. Director Patty Jenkins has cited Mr. Perez's work on the character as an inspiration for her 2017 film "Wonder Woman."

In 1991, Mr. Pérez returned to Marvel to draw "The Infinity Gauntlet" crossover miniseries, elements of which were adapted in the Marvel Cinematic Universe including "Avengers: Infinity War" and "Avengers: Endgame."

"George Pérez made everything look effortless," DC Comics said on Twitter. "His contributions were pivotal in both driving and reinventing DC's long and rich history."

Marvel Entertainment also posted a tribute on Twitter, saying "His work paved seminal stories across comics, and his legacy of kindness and generosity will never be forgotten."

A public memorial service for Mr. Pérez will be held at 6 p.m. ET on May 22 at the MEGACON convention in Orlando, according to his Facebook page.
